title: Emma Watson shines in embellished floor-skimming gown at Shanghai premiere of Beauty and The Beast
text:
Emma Watson looks like she's in a real-life fairytale (Photo: Getty) Share Get celebs updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
While everyone was busy gasping at their TVs on Sunday night, they probably missed Emma Watson dazzling at the Shanghai premiere of her latest film Beauty and The Beast. 
The actress, who plays the role of Belle in the live action remake, looked like a real-life Disney princess in a champagne coloured embellished gown. 
The stunning dress, designed by Elie Saab, also featured a long, flowing cape. 
Her red lips and soft brown eye make-up was completely flawless and co-star Dan Stevens made sure he matched his maroon tie for the occasion. Dan Stevens, Emma Watson, Luke Evans (Photo: Rex Features) Actress Emma Watson (Photo: Rex Features) 
Speaking about the movie, the brunette beauty said: “Pure joy this film, it’s un-apologetically romantic and sometimes we need that. And I thin particularly now we need that. You come out fuller than when you went in.” 
And the star found it “really fun” playing the lead role as the iconic Disney princess because she was able to “pad” out her characters backstory. 
She added to the Mail Online: “That’s the wonderful thing about Belle I feel like even in the original she was very progressive she was kind of a departure from a lot of the other Disney princess characters and so I think it was really just where in the moments I can fill in a bit more of her back story I can pad her out a little bit more, it was really fun to be able to do that.” Actress Emma Watson (Photo: AFP) Actress Emma Watson (Photo: AFP) Actress Emma Watson (Photo: Rex Features) 
However, Emma’s co-star Dan, 34, who was cast as the Beast felt there was pressure on him to do the film justice because he “loved” the fairy tale when he was growing up. 
Speaking previously at the London premiere of the production, he said: “The biggest responsibility I really felt was to myself. I loved this fairy tale growing up and fairy tales in general, and I like them well told, and the animated feature told it well. But every generation comes at a myth from a slightly different angle and maybe reads into it and we need these tales at different times." Like us on Facebook
